docs.lead_paragraph: A host of pharmaceutical companies are working to do for women what Viagra does for men. To do this effectively, they need far more scientific data on female sexual response than is presently available. ''Inadvertently, Viagra has done a world of good in the field of research into female sexual function,'' said Dr. Cindy M. Meston, professor of clinical psychology at the University of Texas at Austin, who has one of the few labs in the United States that measures physical changes in sexual arousal in women. ''After years of very few opportunities for funding, I am now deluged by offers from pharmaceutical companies.''

headline.main: A Boost To Research On Women's Sexuality

docs.abstract: Pharmaceutical companies, working to do for women what Viagra does for men, need far more scientific data on female sexual response than is presently available; Dr Cindy M Meston, professor of clinical psychology at University of Texas in Austin, who has one of few labs in United States that measures physical changes in sexual arousal in women, says after years of very few opportunities for funding, she is now deluged by offers from pharmaceutical companies (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Over the last few years, there has been much debate over whether people who quit smoking are more likely to get into traffic accidents. Now, scientists writing in the journal Nature say they have found no connection. People suffering from nicotine withdrawal can experience physical agitation, visual hallucinations and anxiety, and it has long been suggested that they become more accident-prone. To test the theory, Jackie Knowles, a scientist with the Safety and Environment Resource Center, conducted a study of the rate of accidents occurring on ''No Smoking Day'' in Britain over a 10-year period.

headline.main: Rating the Driving of Smokers Who Quit

docs.abstract: Scientists say they find no connection between quitting smoking and having greater risk for traffic accident (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Researchers who studied infants with low birth weights have found that doses of vitamin A can significantly lower their risk of chronic lung disease and other problems. Newborns weighing less than two and a half pounds have low concentrations of vitamin A in plasma and body tissue at birth. They are unable to digest a sufficient amount of vitamin A during the first few weeks of feeding and thus suffer from poor absorption of the vitamin into the small intestine.

headline.main: A Vitamin Boost for the Tiniest Babies

docs.lead_paragraph: Earlier this year, AIDS became the leading killer in Africa, just 18 years after the infection was first recognized. But if political and religious leaders had responded with effective public health programs much earlier, they might have prevented hundreds of thousands, if not millions, of deaths. Some leaders simply denied the scientific evidence that H.I.V. was being transmitted in their countries. Others mistakenly believed they had more pressing health problems to address.

headline.main: In Africa, a Deadly Silence About AIDS Is Lifting

docs.abstract: Silence of African political and religious leaders in face of AIDS epidemic is slowly lifting; Dr Peter Piot, Assistant Secretary General of UN and head of its AIDS programs, says he sees signs of momentum among African leaders to fight the disease; says momentum promises to slow relentless transmission of HIV, conveyed on continent primarily through heterosexual sex; photo of Piot (M)
docs.snippet: Earlier this year, AIDS became the leading killer in Africa, just 18 years after the  infection was first recognized. But if political and religious leaders had responded with effective public health programs much earlier, they might have prevented...

docs.lead_paragraph: An Arizona fertility clinic says it will destroy hundreds of frozen embryos if the donors do not claim them, a move experts say may be the first time a clinic in the United States has announced such plans. The clinic, the Arizona Institute of Reproductive Medicine, ran an advertisement last month in The Arizona Republic that began, ''If you feel you have embryos or sperms stored with Arizona Institute of Reproductive Medicine, please contact us immediately,'' and warned that all unclaimed specimens would be destroyed as of July 15.

headline.main: Clinic Plans to Destroy Unclaimed Embryos

docs.lead_paragraph: In the beginning -- before, that is, the chest X-ray, the CAT scan, the transesophageal echocardiogram, the prostate-specific antigen, the thallium stress test and the gadolinium-enhanced M.R.I. -- was the physical examination. For most of the last two centuries it was medicine's most elegant diagnostic tool, the best way for a doctor to probe what was going on in a patient's interior. Blood tests, X-rays and scans now often outdistance a doctor's hands, eyes and ears. They can locate and define problems a physical examination can only hint at, sometimes before even the patient knows there is something wrong. Compared with the precision of most common tests, many of the maneuvers a doctor performs at the bedside (''Open your mouth . . . breathe in . . . breathe out . . . and again . . . '') are inexact or even useless.

headline.main: Are Doctors Losing Touch With Hands-On Medicine?

docs.abstract: Medical educators are concerned that a generation of young doctors, dazzled by high-tech tests and computer printouts, is turning away from hands-on skills that, once forgotten, may never be retrieved; many American doctors are no longer very skillful at what is called 'physical diagnosis,' or the art of interpreting abnormalities in the physical examination; drawings illustrate various hands-on techniques used by doctors in physical examinations, and what they see, feel and hears means to them; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: I am not what anyone would call a typical sedentary middle-aged American. At 58, I still do at least one and usually two or three forms of physical activity every day. My regular year-round activities include fitness walking, singles tennis and lap swimming, as well as ice skating in winter and bike riding the rest of the year. So I was a bit taken aback when an exercise physiologist asked if I did any form of strength training. Don't my regular activities keep me as strong as I'm likely to get? Don't swimming and tennis give my arms and shoulders enough of a workout to keep upper body muscles strong? And don't my other activities do the same for my legs and hips?

headline.main: For Younger Muscles, Just Pump Away

docs.abstract: Jane E Brody Personal Health column on strength training as an important element in physical fitness; notes that muscles, to get strong and stay strong, need to be worked regularly against resistance until they fatigue (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: At a 5,000-square-foot gym in Rio Grande, N.J., a half dozen members cluster around a large metal frame with various handles, ropes, bars and built-in benches to help its users bend, stretch and twist themselves into an array of positions. Dottie Drake, a registered nurse and the gym owner, is there to help them master those moves.
docs.abstract: Growing number of fitness centers and gyms are beginning to replace stretching mats with more elaborate equipment; American College of Sports Medicine's 1998 exercise guidelines recommend that people who exercise regularly should stretch at least twice a week to preserve flexibility; photos (M)
